wikipedia_page.main: Robert Francis Thomas Doe,  (10 March 1920 – 21 February 2010) was a British fighter pilot and flying ace of the Second World War. He flew with the Royal Air Force during the Battle of Britain, and was seconded to the Indian Air Force during the Burma campaign.

response: On 3 September, Hughes' promotion to substantive flight lieutenant was promulgated in The London Gazette. He claimed three Me 110s in the space of fifteen minutes south of Haslemere on 4 September, two Bf 109s while patrolling Kenley the following day, and a Bf 109 destroyed plus one probable near Dover on 6 September; he had to break off combat with the last-mentioned when its tanks ruptured, covering Hughes' canopy in oil.Alexander, Australia's Few, pp. 247–250 One of his victims on 5 September may have been Oberleutnant Franz von Werra, who was captured and subsequently became famous as "the one that got away".Claasen, Dogfight, pp. 142–143 Hughes and his protégé, Bob Doe, claimed half of No. 234 Squadron's victories between mid-August and early September.Bungay, The Most Dangerous Enemy, pp. 172, 196

Hughes was posthumously awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (DFC) on 22 October 1940 for his "skill and determination" as a flight commander and "gallantry in his attacks on the enemy"; Squadron Leader O'Brien had recommended the decoration a week before their deaths.Alexander, Australia's Few, p. 264 Kay was presented with the medal at Buckingham Palace on 23 June 1942. In Australia, Hughes is commemorated at Christ's Church, Kiama, with a memorial tablet placed by his sister Muriel.  A special memorial is dedicated to him at Monaghan Hayes Place, Cooma. His name appears on the Battle of Britain Roll of Honour in Westminster Abbey, and on supplementary panel 12 in the Commemorative Area of the Australian War Memorial (AWM), Canberra.Newton, A Few of the Few, pp. 267–268 The AWM also holds his DFC and service medals in its collection. Kay had given the medals to her sisters-in-law to pass on to Percy in the 1950s and, after being lost during an Anzac Day parade in the 1960s, they went through several family members' hands before turning up in the safe of the Kiama Country Women's Association; they were donated to the AWM in 1990.Alexander, Australia's Few, pp. 341–343 On 7 September 2005, Charles Hall's sons dedicated a plaque in Hughes' honour at the house where he fell in Main Road, Sundridge;16 Main Road, Sundridge.  Wynn, K.G. Men of the Battle of Britain. Frontline Books, 2015. p. 257 Bob Doe attended, expressing his thanks for "an Australian who came to help us when we needed him".Alexander, Australia's Few, p. 343 Shoreham Aircraft Museum in Kent unveiled a memorial stone to Hughes at Sundridge on 23 August 2008.Alexander, Australia's Few, p. 344 On 15 September 2014, the AWM's daily Last Post Ceremony was dedicated to Hughes' memory.
